problems.title: Add or XOR
problems.statementHtml:
You are given two non-negative integers a,ba,b. You can apply two types of operations on aa any number of times and in any order:

Now you are asked to make a=ba=b. If it's possible, output the minimum cost; otherwise, report it.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The only line of each test case contains four integers a,b,x,ya,b,x,y (1≤a,b≤100,1≤x,y≤1071≤a,b≤100,1≤x,y≤107) — the two integers given to you and the respective costs of two types of operations.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output an integer — the minimum cost to make a=ba=b, or −1−1 if it is impossible.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the optimal strategy is to apply a←a+1a←a+1 three times. The total cost is 1+1+1=31+1+1=3.

In the second test case, the optimal strategy is to apply a←a+1a←a+1, a←a⊕1a←a⊕1, a←a+1a←a+1, a←a⊕1a←a⊕1 in order. The total cost is 2+1+2+1=62+1+2+1=6.

In the fifth test case, it can be proved that there isn't a way to make a=ba=b.

problems.title: Line Segments
problems.statementHtml:
You are given two points (px,py)(px,py) and (qx,qy)(qx,qy) on a Euclidean plane.

You start at the starting point (px,py)(px,py) and will perform nn operations. In the ii-th operation, you must choose any point such that the Euclidean distance∗∗ between your current position and the point is exactly aiai, and then move to that point.

Determine whether it is possible to reach the terminal point (qx,qy)(qx,qy) after performing all operations.

∗∗The Euclidean distance between (x1,y1)(x1,y1) and (x2,y2)(x2,y2) is (x1−x2)2+(y1−y2)2−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−√(x1−x2)2+(y1−y2)2
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤1031≤n≤103) — the length of the sequence aa.

The second line of each test case contains four integers px,py,qx,qypx,py,qx,qy (1≤px,py,qx,qy≤1071≤px,py,qx,qy≤107) — the coordinates of the starting point and terminal point.

The third line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1041≤ai≤104) — the distance to move in each operation.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output "Yes" if it is possible to reach the terminal point (qx,qy)(qx,qy) after all operations; otherwise, output "No".

You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will be recognized as positive responses.
problems.noteHtml:
Here is a picture that shows a possible movement of the first test case. The coordinates of point r1r1 are (3,1+5–√)(3,1+5).

The first test case.

Here is a picture that shows a possible movement of the second test case. The coordinates of point r1r1 are (1+3–√,0)(1+3,0), and the coordinates of point r2r2 are (−(3√+4)(33(149−243√)√−73√−38)104,−3(1331−7643√)√+123√−27104)(−(3+4)(33(149−243)−73−38)104,−3(1331−7643)+123−27104).

The second test case.

For the third test case, it can be shown that there is no set of moves that satisfies all requirements.

Here is a picture that shows a possible movement of the fourth test case.

The fourth test case.

problems.title: A Good Problem
problems.statementHtml:
You are given four positive integers n,l,r,kn,l,r,k. You need to find the lexicographically smallest∗∗ array aa of length nn, consisting of integers, such that:

If no such array exists, output −1−1. Otherwise, since the entire array might be too large to output, output akak only.

∗∗An array aa is lexicographically smaller than an array bb if and only if one of the following holds:
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

Each test case contains four positive integers n,l,r,kn,l,r,k (1≤k≤n≤10181≤k≤n≤1018, 1≤l≤r≤10181≤l≤r≤1018).
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output akak or −1−1 if no array meets the conditions.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the array a=[4]a=[4]. It can be proven that there is no array that meets the above requirements and has a smaller lexicographic order.

In the second test case, the array a=[1,1,1]a=[1,1,1]. It can be proven that there is no array that meets the above requirements and has a smaller lexicographic order.

In the third test case and the fourth test case, the array a=[6,6,8,8]a=[6,6,8,8]. It can be proven that there is no array that meets the above requirements and has a smaller lexicographic order.

In the fifth test case and the sixth test case, it can be proven that there is no array that meets the above requirements.

problems.title: Token Removing
problems.statementHtml:
Define a sequence of integers aa valid if and only if ∀1≤i≤n,0≤ai≤i∀1≤i≤n,0≤ai≤i.

Define the weight f(a)f(a) of a valid sequence aa of length nn:

For example, f([0,2,1])=2f([0,2,1])=2, because we can remove tokens on 2,12,1 or 2,32,3 in sequence.

JT gives you two integers n,mn,m and asks you to find the sum of the weights over all (n+1)!(n+1)! valid sequences of length nn. Since the answer may be too large, print it modulo mm.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000). The description of the test cases follows.

The only line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (1≤n≤5000,108≤m≤1.01⋅1091≤n≤5000,108≤m≤1.01⋅109) — the length of valid sequences, and the modulus.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n2n2 over all test cases does not exceed 2.5⋅1072.5⋅107.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output an integer — the sum of the weights over all (n+1)!(n+1)! valid sequences of length nn, modulo mm.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, valid sequences are [0][0] and [1][1], and the answer is f([0])+f([1])=1+1=2f([0])+f([1])=1+1=2.

In the second test case, valid sequences are [0,0],[0,1],[0,2],[1,0],[1,1],[1,2][0,0],[0,1],[0,2],[1,0],[1,1],[1,2]. The weight of [0,1][0,1] is 22, and the others are 11, so the answer is 5⋅1+1⋅2=75⋅1+1⋅2=7.

problems.title: And Constraint
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a sequence aa of length n−1n−1 and a sequence bb of length nn.

You can perform the following operation any number of times (possibly zero):

Your goal is to perform the minimum number of operations such that for every 1≤i≤n−11≤i≤n−1, the condition bi&bi+1=aibi&bi+1=ai holds, where && denotes the bitwise AND operation. If it is impossible to satisfy the condition, report it as well.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤1052≤n≤105).

The second line contains n−1n−1 integers a1,a2,…,an−1a1,a2,…,an−1 (0≤ai<2290≤ai<229).

The third line contains nn integers b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (0≤bi<2290≤bi<229).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, you need to output only one integer.

If the goal can be achieved, output one integer — the minimum number of operations required. Otherwise, output −1−1.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, one of the optimal strategies is to use 44 operations to make b=[1,5,4,4]b=[1,5,4,4], which satisfies all the conditions. We can prove that it is impossible to use fewer than 44 operations.

In the second test case, since b1&b2=4b1&b2=4 and b2&b3=0b2&b3=0, then b3&4=0b3&4=0. However, we require that b3&b4=4b3&b4=4, which means it is impossible to satisfy all the conditions.

problems.title: Volcanic Eruptions
problems.statementHtml:
There is an undirected tree with root 11 where each vertex has a weight wi∈{1,−1}wi∈{1,−1}.

A volcano at the root erupts at time 00. At time tt, lava floods all vertices whose distance from the root is at most tt, where the distance is the number of edges in the shortest path between the two vertices.

At time 00, you are at vertex stst with life value SS, initially S=1S=1. Starting at time 00 (including time 00), the following events happen in order at each time stamp:

Find the maximum number of moves you can make before you die.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases TT (1≤T≤1041≤T≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

For each test case, the first line contains two integers n,stn,st (2≤st≤n≤5⋅1052≤st≤n≤5⋅105), denoting the number of vertices and the vertex you start at at time stamp 00.

The second line contains nn integers w1,w2,…,wnw1,w2,…,wn (wi∈{1,−1}wi∈{1,−1},wst=1wst=1), where wiwi represents the weight of the vertex ii.

The next n−1n−1 lines each contain two integers u,vu,v (1≤u,v≤n1≤u,v≤n), which describe a pair of vertices connected by an edge.

It is guaranteed that the given graph is a tree and the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 106106.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a line with an integer indicating the maximum number of moves you can make.
problems.noteHtml:
Here is a picture that shows the tree in the first test case.

The first test case.

One of the optimal sequence of moves is 4→3→4→5→6→7→64→3→4→5→6→7→6, which makes 66 moves in total. The changes in SS is 2→1→2→3→4→3→42→1→2→3→4→3→4. More precisely:

  • At time 00, the life value SS becomes 22 and we move from vertex 44 to vertex 33.
  • At time 11, the life value SS becomes 11 and we move from vertex 33 to vertex 44.
  • At time 22, the life value SS becomes 22 and we move from vertex 44 to vertex 55.
  • At time 33, the life value SS becomes 33 and we move from vertex 55 to vertex 66.
  • At time 44, the life value SS becomes 44 and we move from vertex 66 to vertex 77.
  • At time 55, the life value SS becomes 33. The distance from vertex 77 to the root is 66, which means vertex 77 is not flooded by lava yet. We move from vertex 77 to vertex 66.
  • At time 66, the life value SS becomes 44, but the distance from vertex 66 to the root is 55, which means vertex 66 is flooded with lava.

tutorial.contentHtml:
Sorry for misjudging the difficulty of problem D, but we still hope you enjoyed the problems!

2119A - Add or XOR

Author: YuJiahe

Hint 1

a⊕1a⊕1 is equivalent to a−1a−1 when aa is an odd number, otherwise it is equivalent to a+1a+1.
